case_title: MUHAMMAD INAYAT vs MANZOOR AHMED DHUDRA, ADVOCATE, GUJRAT
complaint_summary: Muhammad Inayat alleged that Manzoor Ahmed Dhadra deceitfully took Rs. 4 lacs for securing acquittal in a murder case involving the complainant's son and nephew. The respondent later denied the allegations and refused to return the money.
investigation_summary: The complaint was diarized on 28-07-1998. Witnesses Ghulam Muhammad and Muhammad Nawaz confirmed the payment of Rs. 3,70,000 to the respondent. The respondent denied the allegations and provided inconsistent defenses, including political rivalry and procedural objections.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal found Manzoor Ahmed Dhadra guilty of professional misconduct. He was removed from practice, and his name was ordered to be struck off the roll of advocates. The complainant was advised to seek civil and criminal remedies for recovery of the disputed amount.
punishment: Removal from practice; name struck off the roll of advocates.
legal_arguments: Discrepancy in the alleged amount (Rs. 4 lacs vs Rs. 3,70,000)
Special oath taken by complainant and witness confirming payment
Respondent's inconsistent defense claims, including political rivalry
assets: Landed property worth millions claimed by respondent
Donation of Rs. 50,000 to District Bar Clerk

witness_statement.Ghulam Muhammad: Confirmed payment of Rs. 3,70,000 to respondent.
witness_statement.Muhammad Nawaz: Confirmed presence during payment; denied prior statement before Disciplinary Committee.

maxims.Special oath: Used to resolve disputes under fear of divine accountability.

legal_terms.Professional misconduct: Violation of ethical and professional standards by an advocate.

words_and_phrases.Illegal gratification: Unlawful payment made to influence a decision.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of professional misconduct against Advocate Manzoor Ahmed Dhadra, who was accused of taking illegal gratification to influence a murder trial. Witnesses corroborated the payment, and the respondent's inconsistent defenses were rejected. The Tribunal found him guilty and removed him from practice.
